Full vainlie is the swete Sprynge 'dyght,</br>And pranckt in every parte,</br>Syth manne ne tastes the trewe delyght,</br>Withouten peace of harte.
The vernalle bloosme, the vernalle thoughte,</br>These give the Sprynge to raigne;</br>'Tis owers — for Zephyre home hath broughte</br>Ower LIEFEST LIEGE agayne!
From Neptune's lowde triomphes he sped,</br>The feare of faithless Gaull,</br>With thousande blessings heried,</br>And Heven approving all.
To HIS owne Paradise HE came,</br>The Pan look'd up and smylde,</br>One arme susteyned HIS peerless Dame,</br>And one THEIR cherub Chylde.
From THEM we coppie Vertue's mein,</br>Reflect Love's forme and feature,</br>Attune ower bosomes to the scene,</br>And harmonyse with Nature.
At THEIR approche the glad Rosiere,</br>A fresher fragraunce takes;</br>And, heark!  the little feather'd quiere,</br>His merriest musique makes.
And couldst thou Patriote false and foule,</br>Brooke a right Patriote Kynge?</br>The venime voyded from thy soule,</br>E'en thou mayst taste the Sprynge.
Poor Martyre of thine owne envye!</br>Why blaste the bloosmynge yere?</br>Let but thy causeless clamours dye,</br>Aeternalle Sprynge is here!</br>
